comments.author: @safsouf1
comments.text:
Merci pour le cours.
Ja'i fait un petit changements sur le code @13:00 avec des commentaries en anglais:

def exemple_porte_variable():
    def define_local():
        Var = 'line 3'  # Here Var is local to define_local() and is not seen outside

    def define_nonlocal():
        nonlocal Var # Here we refer to the local variable Var (local variable of exemple_porte_variable()) declared at line 13
        Var = 'line 7'  # And here we change the content of the local variable Var. So Var variable content will change from 'line 13' to 'line 7'

    def define_global():
        global Var  # Here we define a global variable named Var as if we defined it in main. 
        Var = 'line 11'  # We set the global variable to 'line 11'

    Var = 'line 13'
    define_local()  
    print('After executing define_local(): Var contains',Var) # Here Var doesn't change and keep the value 'line 13', because Var defined in define_local() is local and it is not seen at exemple_porte_variable() level -> Var = 'line 13'

    define_nonlocal()  
    print('After executing define_nonlocal(): Var contains', Var) # At this stage the content of Var at line 13 has been changed from 'line 13' to 'line 7' in define_nonlocal() -> Var = 'line 7'

    define_global()
    print('After executing define_global(): Var contains', Var) # At this stage we are referring to the local variable of exemple_porte_variable() which already contains 'line 7' -> Var = 'line 7'

exemple_porte_variable()
print('After executing exemple_porte_variable(): Var contains', Var)  # At this line, Var is referring to the global variable Var that has been defined at line 11 and nothing changed. So value keep the value 'line 11'

# Output
#After executing define_local(): Var contains line 13
#After executing define_nonlocal(): Var contains line 7
#After executing define_global(): Var contains line 7
#After executing exemple_porte_variable(): Var contains line 11
